posts.name: Emre A
posts.cooked:
What sensors are teams using this year for ball detection?

We‚Äôve had stadium lights interfere with our break beams in the past. What solutions have teams found to be simple, reliable, and robust?

link_counts.title: IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : $5.95 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits

posts.name: Mentor FRC 2992, FTC 25619, past FTC 10337, FTC 14374
posts.cooked:
We have used these photoelectric sensors available from FIRSTChoice in years past with good results.  (Note that the 2020/2021 official field used this same sensor for the shield generator level sensing.)    The sensor has a sensitivity adjustment, allowing it to be tuned to ignore background ‚Äúnoise‚Äù fairly well.

FIRSTChoice also has these and these that I suspect would work well also, though we haven‚Äôt actually used those in any production ball indexer applications.
posts.display_username: Mentor FRC 2992, FTC 25619, past FTC 10337, FTC 14374

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
3468 had really good luck with these IR Reflection sensors for Infinite Recharge.

Electrical Characteristics: U: 5VDC I: 100mA Sn: 3-80CM Size: Diameter: 17MM Sensor length: 45MM Lead length: 45CM  Applications: 1. Production line automatic counting equipment 2. multi-function reminder 3. go maze robot...

These are functionally similar to the Adafruit Beam Break sensors, but with both the light and sensor in one unit. So you generally want to detect the presence of light as a reflection from the object rather than the absence of light on the sensor from the object blocking the light.

Because you can generally try to mount these fairly close to where the object is being detected, as well as adjust the sensitivity to trigger the sensor, we‚Äôve had much few issues with things like stadium lights triggering them inadvertently.

Also, the entire length of the body is threaded, so you don‚Äôt actually have to have wherever you‚Äôre mounting them be RIGHT next to the balls, you have ~2in of travel to move these sensors forward by moving the mounting nuts back on the body of the sensor, giving you pretty fine adjustment capability.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: We used those in 2020 at the top and bottom of our conveyor. Worked great!

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: It can be useful to add some opaque shielding, strategically placed to minimize the effect of any ambient light so the light emitted by your sensor dominates at the receiver.
We used these in our 2020 robot, and they worked quite well.

posts.name: Sam Geckler
posts.cooked:
For the 2020 Power Cells we used Roomba Cliff sensors. They worked very well, but are currently out of stock. There are similar sensors that could work. These are all cheap!

Digikey Part Number: 	1855-1054-ND

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked: For short distances (and if you‚Äôre not afraid to use the I2C port), the REV Color Sensor V3 also has a proximity feature that works quite well.

We used REV‚Äôs Color Sensor V3‚Äôs proximity feature last year; can confirm that it works very well.

This year we‚Äôll be using a Color Sensor V3 too; we were considering using two of them, but due to the I2C problem we‚Äôll likely be using an ultrasonic sensor instead of one.

posts.name: Emre A
posts.cooked: Did you use any kind of shielding for stray IR?

posts.name: JStein
posts.cooked:
FRC 1756, Argos is planning to use the PwFusion ToF CAN sensor again this year. We will be releasing a demonstration video of this in action in the next few days, but in the meantime, here‚Äôs a link to the sensor in action on the 2020 gamepiece. The sensor measures absolute distance, and can be used to accurately and precisely position balls as it can be used to detect the curvature of the ball as it passes by.

We used several of these in series to facilitate ball pickup and staging on our 2020 robot , and it worked very well.

Enjoy! -Justin Owner, Playing With Fusion, Inc Mentor, FRC Team 1756, Argos

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: It‚Äôs a good idea to put black gaffer tape opposite the sensor to prevent direct reflections from the aluminum or lexan walls.
The wall opposite the sensor was polycarbonate, so we didn‚Äôt see any problems.

posts.name: DrewTheRat
posts.cooked: We are using the MXP port‚Äôs I2C to add a second REV Color Sensor V3 this year. I read a little about the two MXP I2C being slightly different, but our testing has shown consistent behavior on both sensors.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: Be very very careful, and test your code thoroughly. The onboard I2C bug can cause a full lockup of the roborio requiring a physical reboot.
